user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_:
```c
bool
MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (const char *const str1,
                               const char *const str2,
                               size_t len)
{
  size_t i;

  for (i = 0; i < len; ++i)
  {
    const char c1 = str1[i];
    const char c2 = str2[i];
    if (charsequalcaseless (c1, c2))
      continue;
    else
      return 0;
  }
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_:
_MHD_static_inline bool
charsequalcaseless (const char c1, const char c2)
{
  return ( (c1 == c2) ||
           (isasciiupper (c1) ?
            ((c1 - 'A' + 'a') == c2) :
            ((c1 == (c2 - 'A' + 'a')) && isasciiupper (c2))) );
}
...
_MHD_static_inline bool
isasciiupper (char c)
{
  return (c >= 'A') && (c <= 'Z');
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rest of the code implements the essential comparison logic and initializations and should not be considered dead without deeper semantic evidence: the loop header and index variable (for (i = 0; i < len; ++i)) are required to iterate exactly len characters; the reads str1[i] and str2[i] are necessary to obtain the compared characters and may have observable effects if pointers are volatile or invalid, so their removal would change behaviour; the charsequalcaseless implementation contains the case-insensitive comparison logic (including the (c1 == c2) short-circuit) and its ternary branches are data-dependent (not obviously removable); the isasciiupper helper implements the character-class test used by the comparison logic and is therefore required. None of those other fragments are obviously executed yet redundant in the sense of being removable without affecting program behaviour, so they need not be investigated for dead-code under Rule 2.2.
